sen.j: シタテルヒメは、日本神話に登場する神道の神である。
sen.e: Shitateruhime is a deity of Shinto described in Japanese Mythology.
sen.cmt: 原文の (神道)を削除しました。
sen.e: Shitateruhime is a deity in Shinto described in Japanese Mythology.

sen.j: 『古事記』、『日本書紀』などに記述される。
sen.e: Shitateruhime is described in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: また偽書である『先代旧事本紀』や『ホツマツタヱ』などでも記述される。
sen.e: She is also described in apocryphal books such as "Sendai Kujihongi" (Ancient Japanese History) and "Hotsumatsutae."

sen.j: 『古事記』では、大国主と多紀理毘売命の娘で、阿遅金且高日子根神（アヂスキタカヒコネ）の妹。
sen.e: In "Kojiki," Shitateruhime is a daughter of Okuninushi and Takiribime no mikoto, and a younger sister of Ajisukitakahikone no kami.

sen.j: 『先代旧事本紀』地神本紀では、大巳貴神と田心姫命の娘で、味金且高彦根神の同母妹。
sen.e: In "Sendai Kujihongi: Lineage of the Mononobe and Soga Clans," she is a daughter of Onamuchi no kami and Tagorihime no kami, and a sister-uterine of Ajisukitakahikone no kami.

sen.j: 『ホツマツタヱ』では、タカヒトとイサコの間に生まれた長女ヒルコ（昼子姫）が、結婚した後に天照大神の妹神として名乗ったとされている。
sen.e: "Hotsumatsutae" describes that Hiruko (Hiruko hime), the first-born daughter of Takahito and Isako, named herself Shitateruhime after she married as a sister deity of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess).

"Hotsumatsutae" describes Hiruko (Hiruko hime), the first-born daughter of Takahito and Isako, as having named herself Shitateruhime after she married as a sister deity of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess).

"Hotsumatsutae" describes Hiruko (Hiruko hime), the first-born daughter of Takahito and Isako, as having named herself Shitateruhime after she married as a sister deity of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess).

sen.j: 『古事記』の大国主神の系譜においては、アヂスキタカヒコネの同母妹と記されている。
sen.e: In the genealogy of Okuninushi no kami described in "Kojiki," Shitateruhime is indicated as a sister-uterine of Ajisukitakahikone.
In the genealogy of Okuninushi no kami described in "Kojiki," Shitateruhime is indicated as a sister-uterine of Ajisukitakahikone.
In the genealogy of Okuninushi no kami described in "Kojiki," Shitateruhime is indicated as a younger sister of Ajisukitakahikone.

sen.j: そのため、高比売（高姫）はシタテルヒメの別名とされるが、姉妹の別神とする解釈もある。
sen.e: That is why Takahime is known as another name of Shitateruhime, but some regard these are the names of sisters.
That is why Takahime is known as another name of Shitateruhime, but some regard these as the names of sisters.
That is why Takahime is known as another name of Shitateruhime, but some regard these as the names of sisters.

sen.j: 『先代旧事本紀』地神本紀では、大巳貴神と高津姫神の子、都味齒八重事代主の同母妹に高照光姫大神命がいる。
sen.e: In "Sendai Kujihongi: Lineage of the Mononobe and Soga Clans," Onamuchi no kami and Takatsu hime no kami have a daughter named Takateruhime no omikami no mikoto, who is a sister-uterine of Tsumihayae kotoshironushi.

sen.j: これと混同された可能性もある。
sen.e: This description can be the source of confusion.

sen.j: 『古事記』および『日本書紀』本文によれば、葦原中国平定のために高天原から遣わされたアメノワカヒコと結婚した。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki" and the main text of "Nihonshoki," Shitateruhime married Amenowakahiko who was sent from Takamanohara (plain of high heaven) to pacify Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (the Central Land of Reed Plains).

According to the "Kojiki" and the main text of "Nihonshoki," Shitateruhime married Amenowakahiko who was sent from Takamanohara (plain of high heaven) to pacify Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (the Central Land of Reed Plains).

According to the "Kojiki" and the main text of "Nihonshoki," Shitateruhime married Amenowakahiko who was sent from Takamanohara (plain of high heaven) to pacify Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (the Central Land of Reed Plains).

sen.j: 天若日子が高天原からの返し矢に当たって死んだとき、シタテルヒメの泣く声が天（『古事記』では高天原）まで届いた。
sen.e: When Amenowakahiko was killed by an arrow flung back from Takamanohara, Shitateruhime's wailing voice reached the heaven (or Takamanohara in "Kojiki").
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When Amenowakahiko was killed by an arrow flung back from Takamanohara, Shitateruhime's wailing voice reached the heaven (or Takamanohara in "Kojiki").
When Amenowakahiko was killed by an arrow flung back from Takamanohara, Shitateruhime's wailing voice reached the heaven (or Takamanohara in "Kojiki").

sen.j: その声を聞いたアメノワカヒコの父の天津国玉神は葦原中国に降りてアメノワカヒコの喪屋を建て殯‎を行った。
sen.e: Hearing her voice, Amenowakahiko's father, Amatsukunitama no kami, descended to Ashihara no Nakatsukuni and built a mourning hut to hold a funeral.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Hearing her voice, Amenowakahiko's father, Amatsukunitama no kami, descended to Ashihara no Nakatsukuni and built a mourning hut to hold a funeral.
Hearing her voice, Amenowakahiko's father, Amatsukunitama no kami, descended to Ashihara no Nakatsukuni and built a mourning hut to hold a funeral.

sen.j: それにアヂスキタカヒコネが訪れたが、その姿がアメノワカヒコにそっくりであったため、天津国玉神らはアメノワカヒコが生き返ったと喜んだ。
sen.e: When Ajisukitakahikone, whose appearance so closely resembled that of Amenowakahiko, visited the funeral, Amatsukunitama no kami mistook him for his own son returned from the dead and rejoiced.
When Ajisukitakahikone, whose appearance so closely resembled that of Amenowakahiko, visited the funeral, Amatsukunitama no kami mistook him for his own son returned from the dead and rejoiced.
When Ajisukitakahikone, whose appearance so closely resembled that of Amenowakahiko, visited the funeral, Amatsukunitama no kami mistook him for his own son returned from the dead and rejoiced.

sen.j: アヂスキタカヒコネは穢わしい死人と間違えるなと怒り、喪屋を蹴り飛ばして去って行った。
sen.e: Angered that he had been taken for a polluted dead person, Ajisukitakahikone stomped down the mourning hut with his feet and flew off.
Angered that he had been taken for a polluted dead person, Ajisukitakahikone stomped down the mourning hut with his feet and flew off.
Angered that he had been taken for a polluted dead person, Ajisukitakahikone stomped down the mourning hut with his feet and flew off.

sen.j: シタテルヒメは、アヂスキタカヒコネの名を明かす歌を詠んだ。
sen.e: Shitateruhime wrote a poem that revealed the name of Ajisukitakahikone.
Shitateruhime wrote a poem that revealed the name of Ajisukitakahikone.
Shitateruhime wrote a poem that revealed the name of Ajisukitakahikone.

sen.j: この歌は「夷振（ひなぶり）」と呼ばれる。
sen.e: This poem is called hinaburi ("rustic song").
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This poem is called hinaburi ("rustic song").
This poem is called 'hinaburi' ("rustic song").

sen.j: （夷振を詠んだという記述は『日本書紀』本文にはない。）
sen.e: (The main text of "Nihon Shoki" contains no description that she made such hinaburi.)

sen.e: (The main text of "Nihon Shoki" contains no description that she made such hinaburi.)

sen.j: 『日本書紀』の第一の一書では、アメノワカヒコの妻の名は記されていない。
sen.e: In an "alternate writing" in the first section of "Nihonshoki," the name of Amenowakahiko's wife is not indicated.

sen.e: In an "alternate writing" in the first section of "Nihonshoki," the name of Amenowakahiko's wife is not indicated.

sen.j: 夷振を詠んだ者の名としてのみシタテルヒメの名が登場し、アヂスキタカヒコネの妹であるとしている。
sen.e: The name of Shitateruhime appears as the person who wrote the hinaburi and as a sister of Ajisukitakahikone.

sen.e: The name of Shitateruhime appears as the person who wrote the hinaburi and as a sister of Ajisukitakahikone.

sen.j: 大穴持御子玉江神社（乙見社とも。出雲大社荒垣外摂末社）：主祭神 下照比賣命
sen.e: Onamochimiko no tamae no kami no yashiro Shrine (also called Otomi no yashiro. A related shrine outside the precincts of Izumo Taisha Shrine): Main enshrined deity Shitateruhime no mikoto

sen.j: 比売許曽神社（難波 大阪市東成区東小橋）：主祭神 下照比売命（江戸時代までは牛頭天王）
sen.e: Himekoso-jinja Shrine (Nanba Higashi-obase, Higashinari Ward, Osaka City): Main enshrined deity: Shitateruhime no mikoto (up to the Edo Period, it was Gozu Tenno (deity said to be the Indian god Gavagriva))

Himekoso-jinja Shrine (Nanba Higashi-obase, Higashinari Ward, Osaka City): Main enshrined deity: Shitateruhime no mikoto (up to the Edo period, it was Gozu Tenno (deity said to be the Indian god Gavagriva))

sen.j: 『延喜式神名帳』では下照比売社が比売許曽神社であると記す。
sen.e: "Engishiki jimmyocho" (a register of shrines in Japan) indicates that Shitateruhime no yashiro is Himekoso-jinja Shrine.
"Engishiki jimmyocho" (a register of shrines in Japan) indicates that Shitateruhime no yashiro is Himekoso-jinja Shrine.
"Engishiki jinmyocho" (a register of shrines in Japan) indicates that Shitateruhime no yashiro is Himekoso-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: なお、比売碁曾社の主祭神は明治以降は牛頭天王から下照比売命に代わっている。
sen.e: Note that the main enshrined deity of Himekoso no yashiro was changed from Gozu Tenno to Shitateruhime no mikoto after the Meiji Period.
Note that the main enshrined deity of Himekoso no yashiro was changed from Gozu Tenno to Shitateruhime no mikoto after the Meiji Period.

sen.j: 売布神社 (宝塚市)：主祭神 下照姫神
sen.e: Mefu-jinja Shrine (Takarazuka City): Main enshrined deity Shitateruhime no kami
Mefu-jinja Shrine (Takarazuka City): Main enshrined deity Shitateruhime no kami

sen.j: 倭文神社（鳥取県）
sen.e: Shitori-jinja Shrine (Tottori Prefecture)
sen.cmt: Web表記にならって (湯梨浜町)は削除しました。
sen.e: Shitori-jinja Shrine (Tottori Prefecture)
Shitori-jinja Shrine (Tottori Prefecture)

sen.j: 現在は建葉槌命が主祭神となっているが、社伝にはシタテルヒメに関するものが多い。
sen.e: Although the current main enshrined deity is Takehatsuchi no mikoto, the history of shrine includes many references of Shitateruhime.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Although the current main enshrined deity is Takehatsuchi no mikoto, the history of the shrine includes many references of Shitateruhime.
Although the current main enshrined deity is Takehatsuchi no mikoto, the history of the shrine includes many references of Shitateruhime.

sen.j: そのため大正時代まではシタテルヒメが主祭神であると考えられていた。
sen.e: Therefore, up to the Taisho Period, it was believed that Shitateruhime was the main enshrined deity of this shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, up to the Taisho Period, it was believed that Shitateruhime was the main enshrined deity of this shrine.
Therefore, up to the Taisho period, it was believed that Shitateruhime was the main enshrined deity of this shrine.

sen.j: 倭文神社内の塚がシタテルヒメの墓であると考えられていたが、発掘により経塚であると判明した。
sen.e: A mound in the precinct of Shitori-jinja Shrine had been believed to be the grave of Shitateruhime, but excavation discovered that it was a kyozuka (mound of Buddhist scriptures).
A mound in the precinct of Shitori-jinja Shrine had been believed to be the grave of Shitateruhime, but excavation discovered that it was a kyozuka (mound of Buddhist scriptures).
A mound in the precinct of Shitori-jinja Shrine had been believed to be the grave of Shitateruhime, but excavation discovered that it was a kyozuka (mound of Buddhist scriptures).

sen.j: 記紀において、卑弥呼の原像をもとに、天上界ではアマテラス（天照）、下界ではシタテル（下照）ヒメとして記載したとの説もある。
sen.e: There is a theory stating that the Kojiki and the Nihonshoki used Himiko as the archetype of Amaterasu in the heaven and Shitateru hime on the earth.
There is a theory stating that the Kojiki and the Nihonshoki used Himiko as the archetype of Amaterasu in heaven and Shitateru hime on earth.
There is a theory stating that the Kojiki and the Nihonshoki used Himiko as the archetype of Amaterasu in heaven and Shitateru hime on earth.

sen.j: そういう意味で、シタテルヒメは卑弥呼をより実像に近い形で記されたものとも解釈できる。
sen.e: In this sense, Shitateruhime can be interpreted as the portrait of Himiko that captured more real image.
In this sense, Shitateruhime can be interpreted as a portrait of Himiko that captured a more realistic image.
In this sense, Shitateruhime can be interpreted as a portrait of Himiko that captured a more realistic image.

sen.j: 記紀の比売許曽神社の記述Tから阿加流比売神とシタテルヒメを同一視し、垂仁天皇の条に登場する清彦は、天日矛の四代後とされており、天日矛が来たのは3世紀前半となり、魏志倭人伝に描かれた卑弥呼の年代と一致するとする説を唱える者もある。
sen.e: Some state a theory that identifies Akaruhime with Shitateruhime based on the description of Himekoso-jinja Shrine in the Kojiki and the Nihonshoki, explaining that Kiyohiko who appears in the section of the Emperor Suinin is four generations after Amenohiboko who came to Japan in the early third century, so it matches with the generation of Himiko described in "The Record of Japan in the History of Wei."

Some state a theory that identifies Akaruhime with Shitateruhime based on the description of Himekoso-jinja Shrine in the Kojiki and the Nihonshoki, explaining that Kiyohiko who appears in the section of the Emperor Suinin is four generations after Amenohiboko who came to Japan in the early third century, so it matches with the generation of Himiko described in "The Record of Japan in the History of Wei."

Some state a theory that identifies Akaruhime with Shitateruhime based on the description of Himekoso-jinja Shrine in the Kojiki and the Nihonshoki, explaining that Kiyohiko who appears in the section of the Emperor Suinin is four generations after Amenohiboko who came to Japan in the early third century, so it matches with the generation of Himiko described in "The Record of Japan in the History of Wei."

sen.j: 兄弟となるアジスキタカヒコネについては、各地の神社の伝承から事代主、一言主、大物主、大山咋神などがその異名同神の可能性が高い。
sen.e: It is highly possible that her brother Ajisukitakahikone is the same deity as Kotoshironushi, Hitokotonushi, Omononushi, and Oyamakui no kami, based on the legends of shrines across the country.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is highly possible that her brother Ajisukitakahikone is the same deity as Kotoshironushi, Hitokotonushi, Omononushi, and Oyamakui no kami, based on the legends of shrines across the country.
It is highly possible that her brother Ajisukitakahikone is the same deity as Kotoshironushi, Hitokotonushi, Omononushi, and Oyamakui no kami, based on the legends of shrines across the country.

sen.j: そのアジスキタカヒコネあるいは父神の大国主、母神の多紀理毘売との組み合わせから市杵島姫（イチキシマヒメ）（宗像三女神、弁才天と習合）、ミツハノメ、アメシルカルミズヒなどもシタテルヒメの異名同神と考える者もいる。
sen.e: Based on the combination with Ajisukitakahikone or the fater Okuninushi and the mother Takiribime, some regard that Ichikishimahime (syncretized with Munakata Sanjojin and Benzaiten), Mitsuhanohime, and Ameshirukarumizuhi are the same deity as Shitateruhime with different names.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Based on the combination with Ajisukitakahikone or the fatter Okuninushi and the mother Takiribime, some regard that Ichikishimahime (syncretized with Munakata Sanjojin and Benzaiten), Mitsuhanohime, and Ameshirukarumizuhi are the same deity as Shitateruhime with different names.

Based on the combination with Ajisukitakahikone or the fatter Okuninushi and the mother Takiribime, some regard that Ichikishimahime (syncretized with Munakata Sanjojin and Benzaiten), Mitsuhanohime, and Ameshirukarumizuhi are the same deity as Shitateruhime with different names.

sen.j: 『ホツマツタヱ』では、和歌の女神和歌姫として記されており、天照大神の妹としてワカヒルメ（稚日女尊）とも名乗っている。
sen.e: In "Honmatsutae," she is referred to as Wakahime, the goddess of waka (Japanese poem), or called Wakahirume as a sister of Amaterasu Omikami.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In "Honmatsutae," she is referred to as Wakahime, the goddess of waka (Japanese poem), or called Wakahirume as a sister of Amaterasu Omikami.
In "Honmatsutae," she is referred to as Wakahime, the goddess of waka (Japanese poem), or called Wakahirume as a sister of Amaterasu Omikami.

sen.j: 他界するとき、アマクニタマ（天津国玉）の娘のオグラヒメ（小倉姫）に、和歌の奥義を記したクモクシ（雲奇）文を授けて、下照姫を襲名させたとされている。
sen.e: It is described that, to Ogurahime, a daughter of Amakunitama, she entrusted a document entitled the Kumokushi-fumi, containing the inner mysteries of waka songs, as well as honoring her with her own name of Shitateruhime.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is described that, to Ogurahime, a daughter of Amakunitama, she entrusted a document entitled the Kumokushi-fumi, containing the inner mysteries of waka songs, as well as honoring her with her own name of Shitateruhime.

It is described that, to Ogurahime, a daughter of Amakunitama, she entrusted a document entitled the Kumokushi-fumi, containing the inner mysteries of waka songs, as well as honoring her with her own name of Shitateruhime.

sen.j: 神上（かみあ）がってから後に、歳徳神と称えられたと記されている。
sen.e: Later, after her death, Wakahime was revered under the posthumous name of the deity Toshinori kami.
Later, after her death, Wakahime was revered under the posthumous name of the deity Toshinori kami.
